The plan contains response objectives and priorities, mobilization and response activities, and pertinent information for contacting outside agencies in the event of a release. The emergency is kept readily available at the site and is reviewed and updated annually. In addition, employees are trained periodically on emergency response procedures. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review

Pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR) are conducted at the Showa facility when a modification to a process is significant enough to change process safety information.  A PSSR is conducted before starting or restarting the process to ensure the as-built condition is the same as the approved design. The PSSR confirms that prior to the introduction of a regulated substance(s) to a process:
	- Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;
	- Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
	- For new stationary sources, a PHA has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup; and
	- The MOC procedures has been completed for the process modifications.

Employees and contractors affected (operating or maintaining that process) by the change to the process are notified and trained prior to operation of that process. 

Compliance Audits

Compliance with the facility's RMP program is verified through safety audits that are to be performed at least once every three years in accordance with 40 CFR 68.79. The compliance audit must be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. A report of the findings will be generated following the audit and all deficiencies and/or recommendations are promptly addressed and corrective actions documented. Incident Investigation

An incident investigation procedure and process has been implemented at the Showa facility.  Each incident that has resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release is promptly investigated, but not later than 48 hours following the incident. Per EPA RMP regulations, a catastrophic release means a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.
In the event an incident investigation is required, an incident investigation team will be established and consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. Following the investigation, a written report is prepared summarizing the following information at a minimum: date of the incident; date the investigation began; description of the incident and any contributing factors; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation. Affected personnel including contract employees will review the report after the investigation is completed.  Incident investigation reports are maintained at the facility for a minimum of five years.

	- Types of Emergencies
	- Emergency Telephone Numbers & Notifications
	- Emergency Response Team Members
	- Roles and Responsibilities

Mechanical Integrity

A Mechanical Integrity Program in an important element to ensure that the on-going reliability of process equipment is maintained thereby minimizing and/or preventing premature failure of process equipment.  A mechanical integrity program is critical to help ensure the safe operation of a process.
Showa has practices and procedures in place to help ensure that processes and associated equipment have been designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to contain those chemicals within the process. Equipment associated with the chlorination process that are used to store, process, or handle covered chemicals are included in the mechanical integrity program. Additional process equipment, safety equipment, and backup safety systems used to mitigate and/or minimize the potential impact of a release are also included in the program. 

Hot-Work Permits

A permit program has been prepared and implemented at the Showa facility for hot-work related work on or near a covered process in accordance with 40 CFR 68.85. The permit is used to document that fire prevention and protection standards in 29 CFR Part 1910.252(a) have been implemented prior to beginning the hot-work operations. Also, the permit lists the date(s) authorized for the hot-work and identifies the equipment to be worked on or near.

Management of Change (MOC)

An MOC procedure is an essential element for any covered process and provides a system to evaluate process changes.  The MOC procedure is used to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and operating procedures for the covered process.  The procedure does not apply to replacement in kind. Replacement in kind is defined as replacements that satisfy the original design specifi

The procedures are intended to provide the necessary information to authorized trained employees on how to operate RMP covered process equipment safely.  Operating procedures are kept on site and are critical in the safe and environmentally sound operation of process equipment. 

Training

A training program is in place at the Showa facility for employees involved in operating a covered process. In addition, new employees working with a covered process receive initial training on the overview of the process and in the operating procedures. Training of employees include emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency response and operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks. Training at the facility consists of videos, hands-on process training, and classroom lectures. Refresher training is provided to employees working with a covered process at least every three years. Training records are maintained on site and contains the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training. 

Contractors

Contractors are used at the facility to conduct various tasks such as maintenance, repair, renovation, turnaround, and specialized work as needed. A contractor management procedure is in place and apply to all contractor activities that have the potential for affecting the RMP covered process at the facility. The procedure does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety. Examples of these incidental services are janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry, delivery, or other supply services.

Process Safety Information

At Showa, this element covers the critical information associated with the covered chlorination process area.  Process Safety Information (PSI) includes three (3) primary areas; hazards (health and physical) of the chemical, technology of the process, and equipment used in the process.  The Showa PSI procedure outlines the mechanisms to develop, maintain and update process safety related documentation and information at the facility. In addition, employee responsibilities are outlined within the procedure.

Process Hazard Analyses (PHA)

Showa utilizes PHAs to ensure that controls are in place to minimize, manage, and control hazards that may potentially affect both on-site and off-site personnel and the environment. The PHA is designed to assist in identifying operational problems, safety issues and concerns, environmental concerns, and associated causes, consequences, safeguards, and risks. An initial PHA was conducted for the chlorination process at the Showa facility.  The PHA was performed using the What If/Checklist method. Any issues identified during the PHA were documented and resolved in a timely manner. The PHA will be revalidated and updated once every five years.

D.	Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Program

Showa has implemented a management program that assigns overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the RMP Program.  The management program assigns responsibilities to individuals or positions that are involved with covered processes. The management program is used to identify, control, and reduce process risks associated with critical operations. 

The facility's Risk Management Program is designed to protect workers at the facility, the general public, and the environment. In the event of a release, passive and active safety systems are in place to help identify the release, as well as control and minimize its potential impact. Plant personnel play an important role in providing safe operation of facility processes, providing reliable maintenance to equipment to prevent releases, and implementing emergency response procedures in the event of a spill/release. The following sections outline RMP/PSM program elements that are implemented at the Showa facility. 

Employee Participation

Employee participation is an important element in any PSM/RMP program.  For these programs to be successful, active employee involvement and participation must be a component. Employee participation is intended to leverage their knowledge, experience and unique perspectives when evaluating process safety matters.  This element identifies the various mechanisms available for employees to participate in the program and defines the minimum requirements relating to employee engagement. Showa has implemented an Employee participation procedure outlining employee roles, responsibilities, and identifying the requirements relating to employee participation.

Executive Summary

A.	Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Showa Best Glove, Inc. (Showa) is a disposable glove manufacturer located in Fayette, AL. As a result of the manufacturing process, the chemical chlorine is present at the facility in a quantity exceeding the threshold quantity outlined in the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention regulations, also known as the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule. The facility has one process that is required to meet the Program Level 3 requirements outlined in the RMP Rule. Showa is committed to operating their facility in a manner protective of their workers, the public, and the environment. As a part of this commitment, Showa has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program that complies with the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) regulations and an RMP program that complies with the EPA's regulation outlined in 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Program. This document has been created to satisfy the RMP requirements and to provide a description of the risk management program at the facility.  This executive summary document was created to accompany the Showa facility's initial RMP submittal to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
Chlorination Process - Program Level 3: 
Chlorine is contained in this process in quantities exceeding the threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR Part 68. A dilute chlorine-based solution is used in this process to help harden the surface of disposable gloves.
